name: Marla Cook
review: The Asus VivoBook S15 S510UQ is not a perfect laptop. Its build could be better, the screen brighter and battery life longer.

name: Glass Nunez
review: However, a 15-inch laptop this slim and light is a real rarity. The 15-inch Lenovo IdeaPad is over 2kg and has worse battery life. Dell’s Inspiron is a similar case: heavier, thicker.

name: Charmaine Elliott
review: We can imagine a more refined take on this vary valid concept in the future. But for now, this is one of your best options if a slim and light but affordable “full size” laptop is what you need.

name: Connie Bradford
review: The Asus VivoBook S15 is a 15-inch laptop that is light, slim and attractive. And it’s not too expensive either.

name: Penny Russell
review: We can imagine a more refined take on this vary valid concept in the future. But for now, this is one of your best options if a slim and light but affordable “full size” laptop is what you need.

name: Greta Randall
review: The Asus VivoBook S15 covers the range of Intel Core i-series processors. If you’re happy with a Core i3, which may well be more powerful than you think, you only need to spend £599.

name: Millicent Wolfe
review: You can spend an extra £100 if you want a Core i7 CPU instead, although the rest of the specs are the same. Alternatively, the S510UA model gets you a Core i7 CPU without a dedicated GPU for £799. But that’s not as much fun, is it?

name: Madeleine Mcgowan
review: Plastic is no limiter on laptop strength, and Acer makes some budget Chromebooks that would probably survive being thrown against a wall, but the Asus VivoBook S15's build is not perfect.
